awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Ecological and Evolutionary Dynamics in a Changing World
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the W.K. Kellogg Biological Station (KBS) of Michigan State University (MSU), in rural Hickory Corners, MI, will support training for 10 students over 11 weeks during the summers of 2018 - 2020.  The program focuses on the ecological and evolutionary processes that drive responses in plant, animal and microbial systems to global change. REU students work in KBS faculty labs that have affiliated positions in departments of Integrative Biology, Plant Biology, Plant Soil and Microbial Sciences, Microbiology and Molecular Genetics, Animal Science, Entomology and Forestry at MSU.  Students will collaborate with their mentor(s) to design a research project that takes advantage of the diverse habitats and long term experiments at KBS to test hypotheses about how climate change impacts both managed and natural systems. Students will participate in a professional development program that addresses issues such as scientific best practices, preparation for graduate school and employment in STEM fields, and effective ways for communicating science. Recruitment targets increasing participation of military veterans, students from under-represented groups, or students from institutions with limited research opportunities in ecology and evolutionary biology. The on-line application is reviewed by program coordinators who forward appropriate candidates to mentors who interview applicants whose interests best match their research. 

It is anticipated a total of 30 students will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research questions are developed and tested, and will present the results of their work at a public symposium. Students will live at KBS, and will interact daily with resident faculty, graduate students and postdocs, who conduct research on a broad range of ecological and evolutionary topics. 

The common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine effectiveness of the training program. Students are tracked after the program and expected to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by contacting the PI (Dr. Katherine Gross at kgross@kbs.msu.edu), or the co-PI (Dr. Danielle Zoellner at zoellne8@msu.edu) or at our website (http://www.kbs.msu.edu/index.php/education/ugrad/reu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site award to the W.K. Kellogg Biological Station (KBS) of Michigan State University (MSU) supported training for 38 undergraduate students from 2018-2022, including 13 students that were funded to return for either a partial or full second summer of research at KBS. Student projects focused on the ecological and evolutionary processes that drive global change.

REUs lived at KBS for 10-11 weeks and worked with resident and visiting faculty to develop independent projects that took advantage of the diverse terrestrial and aquatic habitats at KBS.  Many student projects also leveraged long-term experiments at KBS that allowed them to address ecological and evolutionary hypotheses about how climate change may affect organisms, communities, and ecosystems. REUs worked with a primary KBS mentor to develop and execute their research project and received training and support from a variety of secondary mentors including KBS faculty and staff. Students participated in weekly professional development seminars that addressed science communication, authorship and publication, data management and statistics, and STEM career opportunities. REUs also wrote a two-page research proposal at the outset of the program that included background information, hypothesis, proposed methods, and supply budget. KBS mentors participated in a training program to develop an effective, inclusive mentoring approach to working with undergraduate mentees. REUs prepared a poster summarizing their summer project and presented their research at a public symposium hosted at KBS. REUs also worked with their mentors and KBS staff to create a blog post about their experience as a KBS REU that was posted on the REU program and main KBS websites.

Our recruiting efforts focused on attracting a diverse, qualified, and motivated pool of applicants that would include students from under-represented groups in STEM. Prior research experience was not required to participate in the KBS REU program. Students attending institutions with limited research opportunities (community colleges, small to mid-size academic institutions) and first-generation college students were a priority for selection. Nearly 100% of students recruited to the program fell into at least one of the above categories: women and students that self-identified as from a group(s) underrepresented in STEM fields accounted for 74% of the participants recruited to the program.

REU students in the program were encouraged to present their research at regional, national, and international conferences. Funding from MSU supported graduate students to attend a national meeting with their REU to present a poster or talk, and mentors worked with the KBS Academic Programs Coordinator to secure conference travel funding for their mentees. This pool included three REUs who were ESA (Ecological Society of America) SEEDS fellows that attended ESA either virtually or in person. From 2018-2022, KBS REU program alumni presented 27 talks or posters at a variety of regional and national conferences; 2018-2022 alumni have been further involved in five peer-reviewed publications, as well as two submitted manuscripts and several more in-prep manuscripts.
